text: So basically, Android Studio despite limiting the heap size, once the VM's spin up they saturate my RAM(8gb) and take me to full swap(2gb). That's rough. So I installed Flutter(which took several hours of poking through mysterious java errors and gathering the deps). IE installing flutter means you need a specific version of the JVM, android sdk, etc. So the reccommended thing there is a manager for the jvm and a manager for the android sdk. Then I really struggled to get my phone connected to Flutter (which OOM'd my computer requiring a restart after trying to display a button and a textbox). Some of that was my fault tbh I wasn't using a USB with data lanes.

text: The max heap size of android studio isn't the same as the max heap size of the emulator, those two are unrelated. Flutter shouldn't have taken that long, following the instructions on the webpage plus whatever `flutter doctor` needs should do it last I checked, since it bundles the android sdk. If you're using a real phone instead of an emulator (which I personally prefer), you'll need the USB cable with data lines yeah and obviously make sure adb works beforehand. You'll also run into issues if you use the system adb instead of the one bundled with the android/flutter sdk since adb client and server versions must match.
